item.description:
Organizer: Michael Blair @ (978) 808-1932



UPDATE 12/23: It is winter - there is snow and ice. Snow shoes are required for this hike - so is some form of traction for your boots (crampons are preferred, microspikes are acceptable). You will also need a headlamp. You will be required to show that you have this equipment with you before we leave the trailhead.



This is an updated posting with more information about the route and other trip details. If you have already RSVPed for this event there is no need to do anything else at this time.

I am saving six spots on this hike for people who recently completed the AMC Winter Hiking Program - please indicate in your RSVP if you took the course.

If you are interested in participating in this hike sign up for the established waiting list and answer the required questions. Unless you are someone that I hike with regularly please take the time to answer each of the questions with as much information as possible - even if you have answered them before.



We will be hiking to North Tripyramid (4,160 feet - #32 on AMC WM 4K List) and Middle Tripyramid (4,120 feet - #35 on AMC WM 4K List).

I have never hiked on these trails or climbed to these summits and did all of my current research using the AMC's">AMC's White Mountain Guide, a trail map, and the Internet. The links below provide an overview of where we will be going and include topographic maps of the area. You should become familiar with this information since you are ultimately responsible for your own safety.


  • Click here for more information about North Tripyramid from Peakbagger.com
  • Click here for more information about Middle Tripyramid from Peakbagger.com




Trip Summary

We will follow the Pine Bend Brook Trail and the Mount Tripyramid Trail from the parking area on Route 112 first to the summit of North Tripyramid and then onto Middle Tripyramid. We will follow the same route in reverse to get back to or cars. We should expect winter conditions with snow on the ground - there are several river crossings and any rocks will likely be wet and slippery.

On this moderate pace trip we will hike about 9.6 miles and climb about 3,500 feet (for perspective the top floor of the Empire State Building is about 1,250 feet). It should take an average hiker about 8.0 hours to complete this hike â€“ this does not include time for breaks or lunch. This hike is considered ADVANCED because of the pace, distance, and elevation gain.

WE COULD LIKELY FINISH AFTER DARK SO BE SURE TO BRING A HEADLAMP AND SPARE BATTERIES.

While the objective of this trip is to enjoy ourselves as we climb as a group, your safety, and the safety of the others in our group, is the most important thing. If you underestimate the demands of this trip, or overestimate your skills and abilities, you may put yourself and/or others at risk - consider this before you decide if you are going to participate.

We start as a group, stay as a group, and finish as a group. Our pace will be that of the slowest hiker in the group. If you are faster than the group and don't want to stay with us or want to head off on your own, this isn't the trip for you. Likewise, this trip isn't for you if you are slower than the group and expect us to constantly wait for you or want us to go on without you.

If you have ANY questions about your ability to participate in and complete this entire trip please contact me.

"Reaching the summit is optional, getting down is mandatory."
(Ed Viesturs on the dangers of mountaineering)




Weather

It is winter in the mountains. Dangerous weather conditions will cancel this hike - I will post an update and/or send an email to all confirmed participants a day or two before this event.

Click here for the current weather forecast for this trip.

Mountain weather is subject to rapid changes and extreme conditions. We will assess travel and weather conditions during the hike and make changes to our planned trip as necessary.



Clothing and Equipment

Below is a list describing the minimum required clothing and equipment to participate in this event. DO NOT rely on others to have extra clothing or equipment to share with you once we are out on the trails.


  • Footwear: Hiking boots or trail shoes. Some form of light traction (e.g. MICROspikes) is mandatory. Don't think we will need snow shoes yet but will reassess before the trip.
  • Clothing: Dress in layers to easily regulate body temperature. Wear synthetic shirt/pants and bring a fleece jacket/wool sweater - ABSOLUTELY NO COTTON.
  • Outerwear: Waterproof/windproof rain jacket with hood.
  • Food and Water: High-energy snacks, food for lunch, and enough water to stay hydrated during the trip. Hydration bladders may freeze during winter - bottles with insulating sleeves work best.
  • Other Essential Gear: Map and compass. Plastic whistle. Headlamp with two sets of spare batteries (lithium work best in cold temperatures). Personal first aid kit. An emergency space blanket (e.g. mylar). Small pocket knife or multi-purpose tool. Toilet kit (e.g. hand sanitizer, toilet paper and a zip-lock bag to pack out your used personal hygiene items). Sunscreen. Lip balm. Sunglasses. Waterproof cover for your pack.
  • Optional Items: Waterproof/windproof pants. Waterproof gaiters. Trekking poles. Camera.


You should know how to use all of your equipment - test and adjust it prior to this trip.

I am not certified or trained in wilderness first aid. You will need to bring any medications or medical supplies that you may need during the trip.



RSVP Information

If you plan to participate you must answer the questions for both you and any guests when you RSVP - if you don't answer them your RSVP will be removed without notice and you will be prohibited from participating.

Carpooling is encouraged - indicate in your RSVP if you need a ride or can give one. You are responsible for making your own arrangements so you should check back often and contact others who might want/need to carpool.

Please keep your RSVP up-to-date - if your plans change please be considerate and update your RSVP as soon as possible.

If you don't have a confirmed ride when you RSVP I would ask that you RSVP MAYBE until you have one - once you have a confirmed ride you can then change your RSVP to YES.

All MAYBE RSVPs will be changed to NO three days before the event so people who might be on the WAITING LIST have an opportunity to make the necessary arrangements in order to participate.

Dogs are welcome on this hike provided they are under voice control, you bring a leash in case you need to use it, and you bring a copy of their most recent rabies vaccination.



Directions

We will begin this hike at 8:00 AM. According to Google Maps this meeting spot is about 150 miles from Boston and it should take about 2 hours 40 minutes to drive there.

Click here for driving directions to the meeting spot.
